headline: Easy Gingerbread House
name: Easy Gingerbread House
recipeIngredient:
4 2/3 c.

 all-purpose flour, plus more for surface

more for surface

1 tsp.

white vinegar, lemon juice, or water, as needed
recipeInstructions:
In a large bowl, whisk together flour, ginger, cinnamon, baking soda, salt, nutmeg, and cloves. In a medium bowl, whisk together melted butter, brown sugar, and molasses until dissolved. Make a well in the flour mixture and pour in melted butter mixture. Stir with a rubber spatula until no dry patches remain. (Add a little water, up to 1 tablespoon, to bring dough together if necessary.) Turn out dough onto a clean work surface and knead gently to form a ball. Divide the dough in half and form each into a 1" thick disk then wrap in plastic. Refrigerate until firm, at least 4 hours, or up to 2 days. Repeat steps to make a second batch of dough. Preheat oven to 375º with a rack in the center position. Line three rimmed baking sheets with parchment paper. Print and cut out the gingerbread house templates. Working with one disk at a time, roll dough on a lightly floured work surface to 1⁄4" thick. Use a pizza wheel or sharp knife to cut around the gingerbread house templates, cutting two of each shape. (Gather and refrigerate scraps while you're working with remaining dough; they can be rerolled once.) Transfer gingerbread cutouts to baking sheets, leaving 1" of space around each, and freeze until firm, 15 minutes. Bake gingerbread cookies one tray at a time, until puffed and firm, about 28 minutes. Let cool on baking sheets 5 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely. Assemble house with Royal Icing and decorate.
In a large bowl using a hand mixer or the bowl of a stand mixer using the paddle attachment, beat egg whites and salt on medium speed until frothy. Add 1⁄2 cup powdered sugar and continue mixing on low speed until sugar is moistened. Increase to medium speed and beat 20 seconds. Continue adding powdered sugar in batches until the mixture forms a thick paste. (If using a hand mixer, use a rubber spatula once mixture is thick.)
Stir in vinegar a little at a time, mixing well, until icing resembles the consistency of toothpaste. Adjust texture by adding vinegar or powdered sugar as needed.
Transfer about 1½ cups royal icing to a piping bag fitted with a coupler and a ¼" round tip. Keep remaining icing in bowl, covered with plastic pressed directly on the surface to prevent it from drying out. Pipe a generous bead of frosting on the bottom and one vertical edge of one side of the gingerbread house and position on a serving platter or board. Hold the piece upright, while you pipe a bead of frosting along the bottom edge of a perpendicular side of the house. Affix the second side of the house to the board forming a corner with the first piece. Insert T-pins through the corner to stabilize while the icing dries or place sturdy glasses or cans around the gingerbread pieces to balance. Pipe a generous bead of icing on the inside corner and bottom edge of both pieces.  Repeat with the remaining two sides of the house. Let stand undisturbed in a cool, dry place until the icing sets, at least 4 hours, preferably overnight. Pipe a generous bead of frosting along the roofline of the house. Affix the roof pieces, using T-pins or tall glasses to hold them in place while the icing dries, at least 4 hours or overnight. Remove when the icing has dried.
description: Perfection isn’t the name of the game here. Bake the foundation of the house, raid the candy aisle, and decorate your heart out.
